If you use a hand dryer with an induction motor, it will on average take you twice as long  to dry your hands than it would if you use a hand dryer with a universal motor. This is because with 60 Hz, induction motors are limited to a maximum speed of 3600 RPM. When as with a universal motor as to speed, the sky is the limit. They can go as fast as 20,000 RPM thus moving more air faster and drying your hands faster.

Use paper towels in summer but definitely switch to hand dryers in winter. Infectious diseases such as the flu virus gains protection from the lower temperatures during winter which aids in its infection rate.

From http://www.nichd.nih.gov/news/releases/pages/flu_030408.aspx
At winter temperatures, the virus’s outer covering, or envelope, hardens to a rubbery gel that could shield the virus as it passes from person to person, the researchers have found. At warmer temperatures, however, the protective gel melts to a liquid phase. But this liquid phase apparently isn’t tough enough to protect the virus against the elements, and so the virus loses its ability to spread from person to person.

Also, even using soap or disinfectants (with cold running water) may not be enough to harm the virus with such a protective shell (again, from the same article): In cold temperatures, the hard lipid shell can be resistant to certain detergents, so one strategy could involve testing for more effective detergents and hand-washing protocols to hinder the spread of the virus.

This 80% number gets thrown around a lot recently and it's largely bogus.

1) While it's true that bacteria (pathogenic or otherwise) require both soap and water to sterilize your hands.  It is not necessary to KILL the bacteria to sterilize your hands, all that is required is that the bacteria are removed from your hands.  Though all this is beside the point.  As long as your skin is intact and you're not spending quality time with your hands in your orifices you cannot contract a bacterial infection.  So while helpful, washing your hands is not going to appreciably lower the case rate of bacterial infections since the vast majority I've seen or read in the journals came from a wound, surgical or injection site.

2) With viruses (I did my postdoc in immunology), washing your hands is almost entirely pointless.  All viruses which cause the common cold (with Rhinoviruses being the vast majority of the cases) can NOT be killed with any basic solution that would be tolerable to humans.  Soap will NEVER inactivate a Rhinovirus, no matter how long you wash you hands.  Influenza can be inactivated by soap but there is only one problem... virtually no one gets the flu through touch (I've seen data that only 1% of flu cases are through a touch vector).  The vast majority of flu cases are infected through air transmission (someone that is actively shedding virus in their lungs sneezes--you would be amazed at how far the droplets from a sneeze travel).

The one place where PROPER hand washing does significantly reduce infections...health care.  If you work in a hospital or visit a hospital or are in the hospital, wash your hands PROPERLY often.

I have a question though... Even if dryers can in theory consume less energy than the paper toils, isn't better for the environment that we use more paper? I know, it sounds stupid until you realize that 97% of the paper that we use comes from reforested trees.

The more paper you consume the more reforested areas they might have to have in order to produce more paper. A tree like eucalyptus needs 9 years to grow and in that period while it's waiting to be harvested it stays absorbing carbon from the environment, making oxygen and latter when the paper toil gets to a landfill, that carbon is trapped for at least 50 years, until it decomposes enough where it turn into methane gas and can be reused to produce electricity. 

Meanwhile dryers use electricity that's never recycled back, and this electricity might come from coal, fossil fuels. If you are lucky it can come from nuclear energy or other non carbon emitting energy sources, but the more clean energy we consume, the less it remains to power other things that otherwise will do consume non clean energy. 

I suspect, even I didn't really did the calculation, that even the total amount of energy used to harvest/transform trees into paper is much bigger than the energy used by 2000 W dryer to dry your hands, in the end lots of the energy used to produce paper come from the trees itself (the process is complicated, but 65% of the energy to produce paper can come from the black liquor https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Black_liquor ) maybe in the the end the difference isn't that big at all, while dryers don't contribute to absorb carbon in no way.   

So in summary a dryer perhaps could be worst to the environment than paper toils. And cutting trees to make paper isn't that bad considering that it will lead to more reforestation. 

To be honest, I don't really know the answer to that. But I'm just wondering.

People... Stop saying that paper causes deforestation... This is NOT true. I lived in a small town with the biggest paper factory in Latin America. A lot of people in my family worked there also. Paper is made with Pinus, that they plant a new one every time they cut a full grown one. They don't go out cutting native trees and just expected for the forest never to end... this would be insane.

The only time deforestation occurred was 70 years ago when they first plant the Pinus. They don't need to deforest new areas since although the production of paper is higher every year, a Pinus that took +15 years to grow now is done -7 years, and have a lot less lignin and more cellulose. And the efficient of the system is also way higher.

Besides, all the areas with Pinus have a lot of natural forest, a way higher percentage that is required by law. And Paper help decrease CO2 in the air absorbing it, thing that most people when counting the carbon foot step forgets about it.

And please don't comment that this is only one case... Every Paper factory has to plant it's owe trees since natural ones is awfully bad at making paper. It's cheaper to plant Pinus and have a efficient system than to get natural trees.
